summary:
From July 2020, I have been working as a Statistical Researcher at Statistics Netherlands, team Health and Healthcare. I'm responsible for analyzing medical specialist care data, computing the annual price and volume development for medical specialist care, and investigating the possibilities of correcting for quality of care in this development.

I have a background in Econometrics and after my Master studies I started working at the Department of Public Health, Erasmus MC, where I obtained my PhD in 2017. My dissertation included scientific papers on the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of both cervical cancer and colorectal cancer screening. From 2017-2018, I worked as an Assistant Professor in Early Health Technology Assessment at the University Medical Center Utrecht. In June 2018, I returned to Erasmus MC, to continue my research on cervical and colorectal cancer screening. At that time, I was also involved in studies that evaluated the potential benefit and harm of screening and surveillance for esophageal and pancreatic cancer.

publications.name: Modeling in Colorectal Cancer Screening: Assessing External and Predictive Validity of MISCAN-Colon Microsimulation Model Using NORCCAP Trial Results

profile_positions.description: In deze rol ben ik o.a. verantwoordelijk voor het publiceren van datasets, Statline tabellen en nieuwsberichten over de medisch-specialistische zorg en voor het berekenen van de prijs-volume ontwikkeling ervan voor onze Nationale Rekeningen. Daarnaast doe ik samen met collega’s onderzoek naar de mogelijkheden om de zorgvolume-ontwikkeling te corrigeren voor kwaliteitsverbeteringen in de zorg.
profile_positions.title: Statistical Researcher

profile_positions.description: I've worked as an Assistant Professor within the Health Technology Assessment (HTA) team, which is part of the department of PHM (Public Health, Healthcare Innovation & Evaluation, and Medical Humanities) of the Julius Center, UMC Utrecht. My work included investigating the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of both established healthcare, as well as new healthcare innovations. In light of the latter, I was also part of THINC., The Healthcare Innovation Center, a multidisciplinary team of academic researchers aiming to help (startup) companies to demonstrate crucial aspects like usability, feasibility, and early cost-effectiveness of their healthcare innovations.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor Health Technology Assessment

profile_positions.description:
As a PhD Candidate, I have worked on several projects aiming to increase the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of cervical cancer screening in the Netherlands and Denmark, and of colorectal cancer screening in the United States, Canada, and Australia.
This has resulted in several scientific articles (see below), as well as reports for the Dutch National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM), the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF), and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS).
Moreover, it has led to my PhD thesis, entitled "Reducing Harms and Increasing Benefits of Screening for Cervical Cancer and Colorectal Cancer", which I've defended successfully on April 19th, 2017.
profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate

profile_positions.description: I wrote my Master's Thesis at TNO, department of Sustainable Transport and Logistics. In this thesis I compared different methods to allocate CO2 emissions to customers on a distribution route. I implemented several cooperative game theoretical methods in Visual Basic and compared their computational results in terms of fairness and robustness.
profile_positions.title: Intern

profile_positions.description: I taught the course Macroeconomics to two groups of 30 students Economics & Business Economics
profile_positions.title: Student assistant

profile_positions.description: The aim of the research was to improve the forecasting of future conflicts in the personnel and material schedule due to current delays of trains.
profile_positions.title: Intern
